title: Creating Routines
summary: Establish predictable patterns for daily activities to support executive functioning.

details.content: Consistent routines reduce anxiety, increase independence, and help children anticipate what comes next, making transitions smoother.
A morning routine that includes waking up, brushing teeth, getting dressed, and eating breakfast in the same order each day helps a child start school days calmly.

content: Start with one routine (e.g., bedtime) before adding others.
Use simple, clear steps and practice them together.
Post the routine somewhere visible.
Give reminders and praise for following the routine.
Be flexible and adjust as needed.

title: Visual Schedules
summary: Use visual aids to outline daily tasks and transitions, making expectations concrete.

details.content: Visual schedules help children understand and remember what to do, reducing confusion and increasing independence.
A chart with pictures showing 'homework,' 'snack,' and 'playtime' helps a child move through after-school activities without constant reminders.

content: Use pictures, icons, or written words based on your child’s age.
Review the schedule together each morning.
Allow the child to check off completed tasks.
Update the schedule as routines change.
Keep it accessible and easy to read.

title: Time Management Tools
summary: Introduce tools and strategies to help children estimate, track, and manage time effectively.

details.content: Children with executive functioning challenges often struggle to sense the passage of time, leading to lateness and incomplete tasks.
Using a visual timer during homework helps a child see how much time is left and stay on task.

content: Use timers, alarms, or countdown clocks for tasks.
Break tasks into smaller timed segments.
Practice estimating how long activities will take.
Review completed tasks to improve future time estimates.
Encourage use of planners or calendars.

title: Organizational Systems
summary: Set up systems to keep materials, spaces, and information orderly and accessible.

details.content: Organization reduces lost items, forgotten assignments, and stress, making it easier for children to focus on learning and tasks.
A color-coded folder system for school subjects helps a child quickly find homework and handouts.

content: Designate specific places for backpacks, shoes, and supplies.
Use bins, labels, and folders to sort items.
Schedule regular clean-up times.
Teach your child to return items to their place after use.
Simplify systems to match your child’s developmental level.

title: Emotional Regulation Techniques
summary: Teach strategies to help children recognize, express, and manage their emotions.

details.content: Strong emotions can interfere with thinking, planning, and following through on tasks. Regulation skills support better behavior and learning.
A child uses deep breathing to calm down after becoming frustrated with a difficult homework problem.

content: Model calm responses to stress.
Practice deep breathing, counting, or using a calm-down space.
Label and validate your child’s feelings.
Teach problem-solving steps for emotional situations.
Praise efforts to use regulation strategies.

title: Goal Setting and Planning
summary: Guide children in setting achievable goals and breaking them into manageable steps.

details.content: Goal setting builds motivation and teaches children how to plan, prioritize, and track progress.
A child sets a goal to finish a book report by Friday and creates a plan to read a chapter each night.

content: Help your child choose specific, realistic goals.
Break goals into small, actionable steps.
Use checklists or charts to track progress.
Celebrate milestones along the way.
Review and adjust goals as needed.

title: Self-Monitoring Strategies
summary: Teach children to observe and reflect on their own behavior, work, and progress.

details.content: Self-monitoring builds independence and helps children catch mistakes, stay on task, and improve over time.
A child uses a checklist to review homework for errors before turning it in.

content: Model thinking aloud about your own work and choices.
Use checklists or self-rating scales.
Prompt your child to pause and review their work.
Encourage reflection on what went well and what could improve.
Provide feedback and praise for self-monitoring efforts.
